replies.text: Maybe I am biased but the GitHub copilot Is mostly used within VSC and there users have the choice to use other copilots. Google Gemini is free and codium as well. Giving users the ability to choose the model behind GitHub copilot is just staying competitive

There are a 100 competitors to copilot allowing the user to select from pretty much any of the major models using your own API keys, and some of them are substantially more advanced than copilot. This really feels like a reaction to tools like Cline, Cursor, Aider, etc.

Allowing Claude makes sense because its arguably the best coding AI for the cost. But allowing Gemini is surprising, doesnt Gemini exclusively run on Googles TPU hardware? Microsoft and Google are in a pretty fierce battle over who can build up the most compute infrastructure.

I dont even use gh copilot because Claude is superior I will have to try it out again now if they allow claude This is probably the reason they have been forced to do this, openai is the wrong horse to back imo
But do any of them allow whisper like speech to text, which is in chatgpt?
Is there a Claude plugin already?

25 years ago, McDonalds used to have a decent value proposition it was maybe 60 the cost of a decent restaurant, but it was consistent, fast, and there were other benefits like a kids play room, the happy meal toys, extra condiments were given for free, your large fries was always full, etc... Now there are ZERO peripheral benefits the kids play centres are gone, the condiments are locked up and charged for, the food is less consistent, the portions are _never_ generous, the service sucks... and, crucially, _its like 8590 of the cost of a decent restaurant_. McDonalds is no longer competing against other fast food joints theyre now also competing with restaurants. Their value proposition was their strength and now its gone. 21 years ago a large fries cost 2.00... With inflation that is 3.27 today... Theyre actually charging 5.25. McDonalds decided we arent going to compete on value anymore, and I dont think they realize how much thats going to hurt them now going forward.

From my perspective, its conservative mgmt that has always beat and raised and outpaced analyst expectations theyve also called out in regards to 26 guidance that it didnt incorporate any new products which theyve had new launches since this guidance was released and will inevitably have more. I also personally disagree that a high growth fintech should be valued as a legacy bank most of which have sub 10 rev growth. If their tech platform really accelerates and gets deals with large financial institutions itll be hard to ignore its part of the valuation delta vs banks. Theyve also leaned into originating for other companies no capital loan origination and loan servicing revenue where they dont take on risk. Its possible that growth completely stagnates in 27 but I dont think itll be that mature of company by then. Right now massive tailwinds for company with interest rate cuts, regulatory changes driving demand for tech platform, significant demand for loans for higher income individuals which is Sofia bread and butter. Im extremely bullish over next year , not necessarily beyond that as there wont be as much comparative tailwinds.

If Crox didnt buy HD the stock would probably be 300 right now from buying back 13 of their shares instead and having no debt. But it is what it is, cant change the past. Outside of the poor decision to pay so much for HD, the business is still strong and they are positioning Hey Dude for positive impact long term. They are focusing on DTC for Hey Dude similar to Crox which is a strategy that has increased gross margins and brand loyaltyengagement and to me is a better measure of consumer demand. The of revenue thats DTC for Hey Dude has gone from about 30 to nearly 44 TTM. DTC revenue is only down about 9 while the big majority of HDs revenue drops are from wholesalers. With Hey Dudes branding it makes way more sense for them to focus on digital marketingsales and DTC. Their strategy is not off it will just take time after they pretty much completely reset the Hey Dude strategy a year ago. My biggest gripe with CROX right now is the ballooning SGA expenses. I hope that gets sorted out because they had it down to about 27 of revenue but now its gone back up to 34 of revenue. That needs to slow down, which I think it will. The combination of Hey Dude stabilizing, SGA growth slowing, and a reduced interest expense could give CROX a huge profit boost even without much revenue growth from the crocs brand. Those things are really masking the big gross margin gains over this same period. The bears are constantly waiting for Crocs brand to fall and prove its a fad and the Bulls are waiting for Hey Dude to stop contracting so much and start recovering but the results just kind of keep happening somewhere in the middle. Enough in either direction that you can convince yourself of whatever you want. I increased my CROX share count by a measly 3 today, will probably buy more if it drops another 4 or 5. My long term thesis in the business model of Crox hasnt really changed since I first bought shares in 2020.

I would strongly advise against this. Equity in a private company is not what it seems. The reality is usually that while they may say that you own, say, 50k in equity value, you simply do not have anyone to sell it to. The partners are probably low on cash, hence them offering you equity instead of money. That means that even if you wanted to monetize that equity, there is no way to do it. How much is worth shares of a company that is not making money and is illiquid? Pretty much zero. I would not necessarily advise against having a part like 10 to 20 of your compensation being in the form of equity. Thats a gamble that many people who work for startups make if the company succeeds, you might be looking at early retirement. But in the meantime you have bills to pay and a life to live. Being paid solely in equity is a recipe for exploitation. Before you know it youll be asking for them to pay you some of that equity for pennies on the dollar just so you can feed yourself and will feel like you have to keep working for them without limits, lest their company fails altogether and you end up never seeing the color of this promised value. A startup is all but guaranteed to go through multiple financial restructuring and you can expect early equity to be diluted or wiped out one way or another. So even if the company is ultimately successful, theres pretty high chance that the equity will still be virtually worthless. Its a terrible position to put yourself in and tbh, any serious startup with management worth their salt would not expect the people who work for them to do it without getting paid actual money.

Imagine the company invented a new game like monopoly. They want to pay you with Monopoly money. They are saying when they go live, there will be demand for their Monopoly money. If the game fails to take off, your stock is worthless. Also they can issue how many much ever Monopoly money they want and pay all the contractors. When they go live, the company will be valued and based on how many shares they issued, the share price will be determined. So even if they are successful, your stock could be worth 1 or 0.1 or 0.01 or even lower
cash is king for a reason.

I was going to say 40 an hour is a really low contracting rate, especially if youre an engineer. But then I see youre in Morocco so maybe thats the market rate there. Everyone already pointed out why you shouldnt do that. I would turn the tables on them and ask them for cash compensation and award you the stock as options. That essentially puts the power in your hand by giving you the money and then letting you decide whether you want to purchase those options. As a contractor you might not be privy to as much information as an employee, but this way at least you can opt to keep the cash. Otherwise, yeah, if theyre paying you only in preferred stock, I would treat this opportunity as unpaid. If youre at a point in your life where that makes sense, go for it! Otherwise, yeah...I wouldnt. A few years ago I was asked to essentially build an ecommerce website for my friend. He said he couldnt pay me, but we signed an agreement that said upon launching, I would be entitled to 50 of the revenue up to a certain amount for the first 10 years. Then afterward, Id be entitled to 10 of the net proceeds if he ever sold it. Because he wasnt paying me at all, it kept falling down in priority on my list of things to do. After a while I told him that I dont think I have time to do this unless he paid me. We agreed to void our agreement and part ways. 6 months later he actually paid someone to build the website and when I asked how much he ended up spending, he was like, A lot. If anything, based on what I had in mind in our agreement, you wouldve ended up being a lot cheaper. Never work for free if you dont have to.
If the startup is in preIPO it means you are getting paid in Monopoly bucks

Its hard to overstate how AWFUL this offer is for a prospective employee. I would not even want to work for a tech company that would do this. Its like you are taking a risk on the company making it, but your reward is capped at a rate of return similar to a bank CD or savings account. Preferred shares are paid a fixed dividend. So you will be counting on the company surviving and being able to pay the dividend. However, preferred shares are more like debt than stock, meaning if the company is successful and takes off like a rocket, your preferred shares will not enjoy the same gains as the common shares. You will just get the dividend, which will be like a 5 or 6 return on the value of the preferred. You will not get the outsized 10 to 1 or 20 to 1 returns common shares can get if the startup hits it big.
try paying for dinner with stocks. Stay away.
Paper pollution. The shares will not even get you food. You think your landlord will accept preferred shares in lieu of cash?

Startups fails like 90 of the time, all within a year, the other 9 may fail within 5 years and remaining lucky 1 succeeds to reach the stock market. So would you take a bet of 1 chance of success which you can cash out eventually? Id personally ignore stocks and ask for actual money instead. Holding stocks is a double edge sword as it can be used to claim conflict of interest or intellectual property theft in case you decide to jump ship. tldr bad idea with startup, slim chance.

If I understand correctly, preferred stock does not offer the upside that you would think of when earning equity in the company as part of compensation. Preferred shares have a par value that represents the liquidity preference it has over common shareholders and the value is tied to either preferred dividends with a required rate of return or, I would imagine in this case, a promise to redeem the shares in the future. Above the par value, you are not entitled to any capital returned to shareholders in the event the company is acquired or IPOs. Its closer and actually below in terms of liquidity preference to debt on the companys balance sheet.

Here is a lesson for folks. Stocks in a private start up are not necessarily bad. But you need to believe in the companies vision and leadership. The shares need to be non dilutable. They should be issued based on a reasonable valuation. If you can validateconfirm all of this then it is not a bad way to go if you can stomach some risk. That said to get the answers to these questions you will need to see a data room that has their financials. How else can you confirm if the valuation of the stocks they are giving you is fair? Also almost all of these stocks will be dilutable. Basically getting these requirements are going to rule out 98 percent of the I will pay you in stocks situations. Note that high level execs would get access to these things. This is why when these businesses sell the execs get rich and the plebs get ditched.

Private Preferred stock is difficult to liquidate. Especially across borders. Most regulatory bodies will scrutinize the sale and only allow sales to investors of a certain incomesophistication level. Additionally, the company may block any transaction without explanation as a means to manage exposure on their cap table. It also sounds like their not offering you the shares. theyre offering you the opportunity to purchase them at a valuation of 1 dollar per share. So essentially youd be paying money to work for them in the event you buy them and the company fails. If theyre ONLY offering Pref Stock, and no real cash comp, Id walk but thats just me. not advice. If the company goes public, your shares would likely convert to common stock at the time of the public offering. Youd be required to hold them for a long period of time usually like 23 years then you could sell them on the open market. Heres hoping the stock price is well north of a dollar.
Not only will the shares likely end being worthless, OP will be on the hook for taxes as the face value of the preferred shares will be deemed income by the tax man.

Im not a lawyer, but I definitely recall reading about companies getting taken to court and hit hard for trying to pay their employees in alternate ways that make it next to impossible for them to even access their salary, or force a bunch of it to be eaten up in feesetc. Like for example years ago there were some companies that tried to pay their employees in gift cards with such strict rules that it was impossible to spend the money without incurring big fees effectively pushing the employees salary below minimum wage. They got hammered pretty hard in court for this violation of labor laws. While being paid only in stock isnt unheard of, its usually just very big publicly traded stocks where the person could easily liquidate it on the market. And 100 stock salaries are typically just paid to their CEO, and NOT some random contractor.

Im all for accumulating stock in a startup that has good prospects but you need to get paid money as well. And before Id be willing to take less in wages than Im worth because Im counting on the stock, Id make sure the company is almost certainly going public. The only way to have confidence in that is if theyve already filed to go public, or if the founders say theyre going to have taken multiple companies public before.

So I was a former founder. Preferred shares are not bad but your set up may be bad if it doesnt match your expectations. Getting paid only in stock is completely tied to your level of comfort in the team and their ability to see a payoff in the future. So if this was offered to me early days of Facebook I wouldve taken it right.... So its completely based on the prospects of the team. Now in my case, as a founder I received common shares. I gave my investors preferred shares. In the event of a liquidation event my investor or preferred shareholders wouldve been paid first before me. Also your acceptance depends on how close to the team you are. There are other cases where shares can be sold secondary market. This is usually done before or during a large event that is coming up. So you can sell to someone who wants to get in on the company. So whether it is bad or good is completely up to you and your circumstance. I know people who have made millions from these types of deals as well as most people who have made nothing....

I dont have a lot of contracting experience, but from what I know and have been told by others...For any contracting role, youd probably want to do some research to see how much theyre paying for similar roles for fulltime employees in the area, back into an hourly rate, and apply 50 on top or more as a starting point for negotiations. Going off YOE, youre probably in a senior role. In the US, the tech industry is still in a weird spot, but you can expect 150,000 to 250,000 a year depending on the company. Lets go with 204,000 as a halfway point to make it divisible to 17,000 a month. 20 work days a month, 8 hour days, translates that to 106.25. With that in mind, if I was contracting Id ask for at least 150 an hour. However, in the US not being an employee costs you A LOT in benefits, particularly health insurance. So theres a much larger premium for contractors since they have to cover all that stuff outofpocket. Some of my contracting buddies prefer to do daily rates rather than hourly. It lets them smooth out their earnings as the project ramps up and winds down. I definitely see the value in that I was once contracting by the hour and it was great in the beginning because I was pulling in 60 hour weeks and getting 1.5x on anything over 40. Then as the project was finishing up and I was doing maybe 30 hours a week, I was making a lot less. Luckily, my manager just let me keep clocking in 60 hours so it worked out.

Preferred can be either. Traditionally for mature companies, preferred acts similar to bonds but later in line on liquidation so higher interest rates. Preferred on startups typically dont. They act in many ways closer to common shares except they get liquidation preference. Typically given to people who put money into the company directly so they will see all their invested money back before common shareholders see a dime.

Lots of knee jerk scoffing and ranting about the TPRCPRI merger block. Sure, at the most superficial level it sounds funny to care about two fashion brands merging. But if you read the actual case, and FTCs mandate, then its quite clear why they were right to pursue it and why every qualified panel and judge who has looked it at in careful detail agreed wholeheartedly. Its not just about having choice and capitalist consumerism for handbags or jackets. And its not just about protecting the interests of the employees, tenants, suppliers, and coretailers. Its about blocking the deliberate and patent creation of a exploitive monopoly, something thag is in FTCs mandate to prevent. And by doing so, with unanimous confirmation by every qualified expert, it sends a proactive message to other corrupt opportunist in any sector or business who might have wanted to try their luck at flouting our antimonopoly laws. Some who understand this deeper reasoning may still complain that truly big monopolies or oligopolies are not being held to account as strictly. But a properly functioning FTC has to prioritize winning cases along with going up against behemoths who will go to any lengths. FTC winning some cases establishes good precedent and acts as a deterrent.

However, the fundamentals are still not crazy expensive for the company. One thing for a lot these type of businesses is the importance of the backlog and its still pretty strong. From the ER from earnings. Backlog as of September 30, 2024 was 5.68 billion as compared to 5.77 billion as of June 30, 2024 and 4.29 billion as of September 30, 2023. On a samestore basis, backlog increased from 4.29 billion as of September 30, 2023 to 5.17 billion as of September 30, 2024. Mr. Lane continued, Backlog continues far above the levels of the prior year and bookings were remarkable even as we are burning through work at a record pace, with samestore revenue higher by 18 on a quarterly basis, and by 23 yeartodate, compared to the prior year. Entering the fourth quarter, samestore backlog is 21 higher than it was at this time last year, and we are experiencing unprecedented strength in our pipelines. Considering these advantages and given the confidence we have in our unmatched workforce, we expect continued strong results in the fourth quarter and in 2025. best of luck with whatever decision you make!

Maybe you know this and maybe you dont, but those reports are always revised and no secret goblins are secretly creating fake secret numbers that wouldnt fool or influence anyone anyway. Thats just the nature of how that reporting process is. ___ Edit on the off chance someone else wants to know why jobs reports get revised, its because the initial report is based on best estimates from employers of their hiring plans, and the revisions reflect more the actual hires that took effect. One is more timely. The other is more accurate, but lagged. They are always revised. And the revisions tend to follow patterns related to phases of the cycle, and can sometimes inflect. So theres no reason why you would expect them to alternate like a coin toss. Its very typical for there to be a series of downward revisions in a sequence or a series of upward revisions in a sequence. Theres no boogeyman hacking the numbers for some vague and mysterious purpose. Someone knowing that can protect themselves from being tricked by certain hoax sources who try to create undue division and paranoia with conspiracies.
Bad economic data real. Good economic data fake. Downward revisions real. Upward revisions fake. This kind of stupidity getting upvoted on an investing subreddit is pretty astounding.

China is also amenable to working with them when theres mutual benefit but doesnt want to upturn everything in the same way thankfully, they prefer the long game of building influence while undermining the USs until they are strong enough to project force. There is a significant risk that Russia or Iran miscalculate and do something that ends up pulling NATO troops in directly. Also Trump winning will cause this stock to randomly sell off over the next 4 years as he berates Bezos in public and works behind the scenes to screw Amazon over. I believe Google is well positioned moving forward but they dont give investors the same sense of confidence as other big tech names.

Teslas net income is down 32 yy through the first three quarters of the year. Not good. Their original guidance was 50 CAGR from 2020 2030. They were above 50 through 2023. Through 2024, their CAGR looks like itll be dropping to around 38. If they maintain a similar unit sales volume in 2025, itll drop to 30. Not good. Tesla has a forward PE of over 72 right now, which will be even higher tomorrow. Other OEMs, who have performed far better than Tesla recently, are sitting around forward PEs of 57. Teslas valuation heavily relies on the idea of constant future growth. Their robotaxi event was generally scoffed at. Not good. It was fairly expected theyd beat estimates, and given how shit the stock has been lately, that often leads to a short term pump. I could see a 61.8 retracement by the end of the month from wherever its high is over the next 12 days probably right around 240, dropping to 222. Then I imagine itll pop back up to a lower high around 250255. Then, its likely all down from there, likely back down to around the 160175 area by beginning of next year... lining up with quarterly sales figures which I dont expect to be spectacular. Maybe it beats last year, but that isnt saying much when they were previously claiming a 50 CAGR. Why this stock is worth so much more than other auto OEMs is probably a question a lot of major investors are asking themselves. A lot of them were betting on autonomous taxis... but Musk can only claim its 12 years away for so long before they eventually start to wise up. 10 years... hes been claiming that every year for 10 years straight now The stocks a dog, Meme investors just dont know it yet. Its been in a long term downward trend, no doubt supported by a core of buy and hold forever insiders and cultists, and of course SP index funds that will only sell if everyone else does. Hell, GM is outperforming it... _________ Imagine where this company would be if they werent pulling in 10 billion in government subsidies and regulatory credit sales every year...

Regulatory credits are 100 income 100 corporate profit. Comparing the first 3 quarters of the year, their regulatory income is approximately 700 million higher than the previous highest year. Their net income through the first 3 quarters is 4.807 billion, versus 7.069 billion last year, or 32 lower yy. Just to repeat from my last comment, and add a bit more info, regulatory credit isnt simple revenue... its 100 net income... 100 profits. 739 million is 33.6 of Q3s net income. Keep in mind, a massive chunk of their remaining net income comes from government subsidies. In the US for example, theyre still seeing 7500 federal tax credits on a large percentage of their total sales which allows them to maintain higher MSRPs, translating into higher profit margins. Most of their sales are in states with state EV tax credits as well, often in the 15002500 range. Some as high as 5000. Their energy sales are even more subsidized than their car sales. The federal government subsidizes something like 30 of the overall cost of a solar panel home battery storage installation. States with the highest rooftop solar adoption rates often have additional incentives on top. Overall, it can reach up to 50. Im not sure on their grid scale power storage, but Im guessing the subsidies andor the amount theyre charging the government, which often has mandates written into law to have storage installed, are lucrative. Like 2023... if Tesla were to exclude regulatory credit income and government subsidies from their income, theyd likely be reporting a loss for 2024. I guess this doesnt technically matter unless there were a risk that the subsidies were going to disappear in short order.. which theres no sign of. Some headwinds for Q4 Theyve removed their lowest priced trim model 3 near the end of Q3, which had the imported Chinese LFP battery. That could hit their overall sales numbers in Q4. It also means theyre not going to sell cars with the significantly cheaper LFP packs, which likely generated some decent profit margins. These units didnt qualify for the full tax credit on sales although I do believe they still qualified on leases, which Tesla would have had to roll into the lease price. Not sure if they did or didnt do that. They significantly cut the price of the Cybertruck and still dont seem to have a backlog after the price cut per their estimated delivery dates on their site. Theyve significantly cut the prices on their inventory vehicles. Model 3s Ive seen have up to 3k discounts applied. Model Y has as much as 4k discounts applied. I used to work for a guy at a global logistics company. We were tasked with building something that had never been built before, using Machine LearningTM. The idea is simple. The theory is pretty simple. The actual construction of something that is as good or better than a human at performing a job.... Very difficult. We did not succeed and the project was cancelled. Now we were a motley crew to say the least most of my coworkers were Serbian and frankly not very intelligent. Nevertheless, I dont foresee the brightest minds solving the problem. I equate the problem of having a computer do human tasks like driving a car to putting a man on the moon, curing HIV, or harnessing nuclear fusion. The THEORY is straightforward. The implementation often requires the literal invention of new elements and materials in the case of NASAs Gemini, Apollo and Space Shuttle programs. So we know at a high level how to build FSD. I guarantee the guys at Tesla working on it have the theory nailed down. The implementation is what they are struggling with. Like driving, perfection is required to get people to and from space safely, cure HIV, or harness nuclear fusion. This is not shit that can be wrong half the time or even 20 of the time like ChatGPT. ChatGPT is childs play compared to FSD. Elon being an arrogant idiot failed and probably still fails to realize why FSD is more like nuclear fission than BonziBuddy.

Cradle to grave assessments dont cover things like mining. Ive been in the EV community and been researching this topic for a very very very long time, bud. There are certainly unknowns that are never mentioned or covered, which is why I mention those things out in my comments. For example, I didnt say increased cost of battery production. I specifically noted the high front loading of high emissions. Why did I mention this? The planet can only sequester so much carbon over a given period. What happens if we significantly increase the amount of carbon we produce in a given year on account of a manufacturing process that spikes the levels of emissions? What are the impacts to the environment? Does it result in more ocean acidification, because the CO2 is sucked up by the oceans instead of the forests? Thus leading to devastation of coral reefs and oceanic plant life, and styming the Oceans ability to sequester more carbon? Again, not something covered in cradle to grave assessments.. Sure, power grids are changing... slowly... and will continue to do so over time. That doesnt mean there arent significantly better solutions to the environmental problem than simply MOAR CARS!. Were to the point where every bit of CO2 we inject into the atmosphere will likely require more energy and time to suck back out of the atmosphere in the future with CO2 sequestration processes. IMO, the best solution is to not emit in the first place. We, humans, need to drastically reduce our carbon footprints in a very short period of time. BEVs help, never said they dont. Dollar for impact... theyre about the slowest solution for reducing global emissions.

I get it, Tortoise vs Hare. The reason you want to park money into staples is precisely that they have a high likelihood of being around in 40, 60, 80 and 100 years and they are very likely to keep growing the entire time. This is why staples are powerful. For instance, pull up a sector market share chart. If you do that you will notice something interesting. Techs market share has actually gone no where since the late 60s. It peaked in the .com bubble and is again in a slight bubble now, but overall, not changed since then. What has changed is the companies within. Lots of boom and busts and big time consolidation and concentration of value. Staples havent really changed much either in terms of market share but like I try to describe above, its very easy to pick winners from staples precisely because they are not boom and bust. At worst, they get bought out but they will never go obsolete. This low risk characteristic is extremely valuable because even a dummy can pick winner 90 of the time. You cant say that about picking tech or finance or even energy stocks. Are the big tech giants of the 60s still around? Some yes, but mostly no. Are all those popular fracking companies from the 2000s still around? Most went under in the financial crash. And banks are like revolving bankruptcies even if they dont go under entirely.... Folks need to start respecting risk and practice risk mitigation. There is a total disregard for that on this channel in favor of getting rich quick on the next double or 10 bagger. MSTR has increased the bitcoin it owns this year by about 33 and has increased its current share count roughly 15 through convertible debt offers resulting in a current increase of BTC per share of about 18 YTD. There is still no clear relationship between bitcoin and its price. It does not get cash from any operations like a company does. Bitcoin has no future cash flows. It is an asset with a price because people think it has value, just like goldsilverbeanie babies. The technology behind bitcoin is very real, and will one day maybe lead to some new change, but the price is a question mark. There is no clear relationship. The secret is that the core of peloton is a content subscription service model. People who like or need a coach, trainer, instructor. They are shockingly loyal, with Costco level retention. For them, a sub is 40 a month for a couple, versus paying 20 times 10 sessions for classes. They feel they are saving money and being healthy. Where theyve done well is when they focus on the subscription model and stay out of hardware. This announcement is mixed. It teases the possibility of subscriber growth, but it also hints theyre headed back to hardware sales which nearly destroyed them.

Have you never done a fitness class? Some people thrive in that environment as opposed to working out alone, but are not able to make in person classes work with their schedule. Peloton also gamifies fitness to an extent, which can help people get into the habit of working out. Its not for me, but my wife loves it and I can see why people buy and subscribe.
Lmao. Probably the same reason people sign up for weight watchers or a gym membership.
Lmao. Cool story bro. Super amusing how emotional you are about a product you have never used. You must be enlightened.

No, you just misread what he said. Hes saying you dont need a subscription with an instant pot. But you do with a peloton. But what the problem OP was referring to is that buying peloton and instant pots are one time purchases. Once you have one, you dont need to buy another one. Its hard for a company to grow when you have no more customers to buy them.

Yes, Apple Fitness is available on Apple TV. I use it on mine to use Fitness on the big screen with my C6 bike right in front. The iPhoneiPad support for Fitness was only added a year ago, actually, as many people wanted to be able to access Fitness on the go without having an Apple TV with them!

For a single person, peloton is kind of mid unless you are die hard with exercise classes. As a couple, like my wife and I, its big value. I use the bike classes and my wife does everything from bike to yoga. For 40 a month thats a pretty good deal for two people.

Some people thrive in that environment That environment being the key part that eludes me. Prefer a social environment to work out with social encouragement? I totally get that. Peloton doesnt replicate that, youre cycling alone. Dont mind working out alone in which youre only connected to others digitally? It seems like that can be had at far less cost in a far higher quality via other means, right?

A gym membership feels entirely dissimilar in that it involves equipment that many dont have at home. Thats one big reason that I have a gym membership. Pelotons core equipment can be bought at a far higher quality for far less cost elsewhere, hence my confusion. Weight Watchers lol? People still utilize that?
You sounded sooooooo cool and rich when you called me a bozo. You must be so cool irl.
removed

Sorry, I wasnt clear on my question. As far as I understand, the C6 will connect via Bluetooth to an iPad to share cycling data with compatible apps. I was wondering if the C6 will also connect to an Apple TV via Bluetooth to share that same data.

Maybe but cost isnt always the determinative factor for people and Peloton knows their target audience is not the costsensitive consumer. Anyone buying inhome workout equipment is already not very costsensitive and is likely looking for an alternative to a gym. Ill admit that my Peloton Journey was not longlived. But I consistently worked harder on that bike and in those classes trying to beat my PR and other randos that were taking the class at the same time as me than I have on a solo exercise bike. Ive got family and friends spread around the country and its cool to keep up with their workouts and occasionally join as well.

The reason people get the product is the same. And the only people who say the bike sucks have never used a stationary bike before. And based on the advertising i see, yes weight watchers is still a thing.
I actually have a 125 week streak going. And buns of steel. Thanks for asking.

Gotcha. Sorry, then. Im not sure. I just have my C6 connect via Bluetooth to my Apple Watch, which syncs info to the Fitness and Health apps on iOS natively. I do recall some people elsewhere on Reddit and other forums explaining that there doesnt appear to be a way to have the C6 connect to Apple TV natively.

Like I said, Pelotons core equipment can be bought at a far higher quality for far less cost elsewhere, hence my confusion. ... so perhaps it comes down more to branding and advertising, as I suggested?

This could work connecting it to my Apple Watch. I really only want the Apple TV to watch workout videos, but I would love to get my C6 data synced to my Health app. I still havent set it up, but Ill play around with the options once I do. Thanks for the info!
Bud you are just guessing. There absolutely arent stationary bikes of far higher quality for far less cost Why are you pretending that you have been out there trying multiple stationary bikes...

If youre just looking to track distance, speed, heart rate, etc., the Apple Watch sync will be all you need. Between the Apple Watchs stat tracking and Fitness data, youll basically have everything you need to see how youre performing. Cheers!
Sorry for your poor guess! Ive used Peloton bikes a few times friends bikes, I havent owned one and use a very simple trainer setup with my bike at home.

MCO Moodys raised its earnings outlook after reporting a jump in profit and revenue for the third quarter amid a rise in transactional revenue. The creditratings and research company said Tuesday it saw a profit 534 million, or 2.93 a share, compared with 389 million, or 2.11 a share, in the yearago period. Adjusted EPS came in at 3.21, above analyst views of 2.87, taken from FactSet. Revenue came in at 1.81 billion, compared with 1.47 billion. Analysts were expecting 1.71 billion, according to a FactSet consensus. The company said transactional revenue grew 70, reflecting heightened activity from infrequent issuers across all lines of business. Moodys Investors Service revenue rose 41 to 1.0 billion, while the Analytics division was up 7 at 831 million. Looking forward, the company raised adjusted EPS guidance for 2024 to between 11.90 and 12.10, from its previous range of 11.00 to 11.40.

Rate cuts are bullish but for a variety of reasons people are beginning to doubt the Feds rate cut path.

SHW earnings were pretty poorly received and sending ripples through the building industry. Mortgage rates are actually not going down, however, if they did go down it makes new houses cheaper and helps builders. If mortgage rates were to go down again, builders would see a boon. Odd lots just did a show on mortgage rates. Basically, its hard for rates to drop when investors know that there will be a refi rush as soon as rates drop. Great listen if you get the chance. I sold my DHI position about a month ago because of the changing dynamics.

Not sure if thats what they said, but one thing Ive called out here also just my opinion, is that lower rates will actually hurt the builders, since lower rates could unlock more used inventory. Historically used homes make up a vast majority of the housing market and because of the high rates and low inventory, new homes actually have been selling at higher rates. Also, new home builders can offer things like mortgage buy downs to draw people in. We are still going to need to build a ton of housing, just as rates go lower in the future and more used inventory becomes available, people will probably buy less new homes. Not saying home builders are a bad investment, just my fear is that theyve hit their peak in terms how much units they historically move. This spring, new home sales are a more important part of the market than they would be in a more typical year, says Lisa Sturtevant, chief economist for Bright MLS. In April, new singlefamily home sales were about 14 of total home sales nationwide. Typically, sales of new singlefamily homes account for less than 10 of all sales transactions, and the last time the new home share was this high was back in 2005.

replies.text: Imagine the gains youd make if you simply didnt invest in companies with scandals or sour sentiment.

BABA is up 25 over the past year while VOO is up 38 so thats not the success story youre making it out to be. Success in the market isnt just making a profit. If youre not beating the SP then youre losing. Bear in mind that while youre sitting on cash waiting for the next piece of bad news, that money isnt appreciating like it would with a set it and forget it approach. Also every time one of your picks starts to plateau and you decide to sell you have to give the tax man his cut which means you have less to reinvest. If you have to sell before youve owned the stock for a year then youll have to pay capital gains which will cut into your profit even more. All these things plus the fact that there isnt a guarantee that a stock will bounce back from bad news means that this is probably not the slam dunk you think it is. You may get lucky a few times but its probably not a sustainable investing strategy.
its an ETF world and we just live in it. results dont matter because of the sheer amount of macro spend in buying index and baskets. thats why mag7 and sp is unstoppable right now.

replies.text: Im not WH or 40K player, but it always struck me as weird how terrible a job GW has done in expanding their fanbase. Theyve been around as long as TSR RIP and their products are just as old as Dungeons and Dragons, but it seems like theyve never been able to generate the same scope of mass appeal as TSRWotCHasbro has been able to create and maintain. Obviously tabletop gaming is a far bigger money and time sink than RPGs where most players wont buy anything more than one players handbook, so the percustomer profit is higher at the expense of the number of customers. But I mean more in terms of leveraging their IP in other areas in QUALITY ways. There are a ton of Warhammer and 40k games being churned out all the time, but most are, as far as I can tell, pretty crappy. I dont know why GW has never been able to turn out something as memorable as anything from the Baldurs Gate series, Neverwinter Nights, or Planescape Torment. It seems like their inability or unwillingness to take that next step puts a growth limit on the company.
GW is a compounder with great margins. I own it too and wont sell for the next couple of years. Cant give you advice on short term action I just dont know and care that much.

If you dont plan to hold long term, I would sell now. The price will likely hold steady. I dont know how much the market price in Amazon, but I dont think the deal is safe in any way. Instead, they slowly increase manufacuring. But leadership is very risk adverse to increasing capacity. So its slow. The big gain will come from digital games, like space marine 2, total war, etc. The latter looks to be in the works of yet another warhammer game. The big risk is any downturn that decrease physical sales. A market turn where people cant afford hobby items or fan outage of e.g Amazon show akin to lotr.. Its a slow company, I wouldnt expect much the next couple of months.

GW have put a limit of the end of the year to come to a deal, or theyre pulling the plug. They could have another streaming company to take over instead of Amazon if Amazon declines. I think its likely to happen but that doesnt mean the movie will be good, a hit, or make money.

I think GW will do well from the games hype. Its done well at reviving the mans game like gears of War did on 360. The demographic of players will align well with GWs other products. The road map extends into next year so maybe see how the player base responds over the holiday period. If your happy with your gains take them.

I looked at GW a few months ago and wanted to buy but it looked a bit too pricey. The CEO has done a good job since he took over. Look at the price fluctuation when stream deal was announced to see whether its impliedbaked in to current price

GW is a company called follow and I do like but it does seem like theyre limiting their IP in some aspects. Ita popular but still on the grand scale a niche product. If the Amazon deal pops off it could be a nice return but for me itd be something I put a lot of money into long term or build up over time.

Their profits increased from like 14ish million to 170ish million over the course of the past 10 years. Their revenue went from 200 million to like 450 million over the past 10 years. Even during the COVID pandemic they went up. I think they are a safe bet to hold for January or next year. For their main industry, which is tabletop miniature wargames, thats really really good. Most of their competitors that make similar games are nowhere near those numbers. Catalyst Game Labs, for example, are nowhere near those numbers and Mechwarrior is pretty well known. But Games Workshop is historically really good at fumbling the bag to the point theyve almost gone bankrupt a few times over their history, but the last time was over a decade ago so maybe theyve got their act together.

Im hoping this sustains for a while, until at least around the mini ep is on that amzn show. Im hoping space marine 2 success leads conversion into minis, gw aint had a big win in gaming like this before.
Game workshop looks interesting actually.

They seem to me to have the most undervalued IP of anyone. Whether they have the sense to recognise it, and the ambition to exploit it, remains to be seen. If the Amazon show is successful, its massively going to grow interest in the hobby and various merchandise. Not sure how much thats priced in.
Gaming stocks whether video game or tabletop are VERY RISKY and volatile, from my experience.

Yeh Warhammer hasnt had close to the same cultural impact as something like DnD! I think whats kept them in business, though, is the average spend of a hobbyist. Ive probably spent as much on Warhammer in a year or so of being a fan as I have in 10 years of playing DnD. Historically, Warhammer games have been hitandmiss. The Dawn of War series did quite well as did Space Marine 1, but both I dont think wildly reached outside GWs traditional audience. My bet, which turned out to be correct, was that Space Marine 2 in particular was going to be a good enough game to break out of GWs typical audience and that this would drive increased footfall. Im not taking a longterm position on the company, just trying to capitalize on this one particular event. The question is if thats best served by waiting till the January sales report or cashing in now

They also self destructed their original Warhammer business right before accidentally releasing good game adaptation for it. Also known for price gouging and quality cutting on models. I dont know much about the company, but they behave like venture capitalist flippers, aka extremely incompetent and shortsighted.
Totally agree.
Agree on the company being a compounder due to the high margin. Is it shareholders friendly, though?

Yeh I dont necessarily care about a showmaking money, because that would probably mostly go to the production company. What I care about is it being perceived come January as a likely enough hit to push the stock price up!
Yeh I think what Im most concerned about is that an Amazon deal falling through will knock the stock price and overshadow good winter 24 sales figures.

On the longterm value of the IP... They do and they dont. I think they have some exceptionally recognisable motifs. Space Marines are phenomenally recognisable and have hit the level of cultural saturation comparable to things like Lord of the Rings. What I mean by that is that without even realizing it, so much fantasy references LotR, and in the same way look at any design of a space super soldier and its probably going to incorporate some of the visual aesthetics and concepts of a Space Marine. But on the other hand, to be frank, the lore is a MESS from a storytelling perspective. I dont blame the writers for this, to be clear. Abnet and co. were writing under very unusual conditions of having to pump out pulp fiction at a phenomenal rate alongside I think five different edition changes, each adding to the future lore. The Horus Heresy series, which I take to be the biggest contribution to the lore, has the feel of a bridge being built as the train is riding along. This isnt their fault, actually it can be quite charming, as it was a product of their writing conditions. But the Heresy as is is not accessible. Its simultaneously too rushed and too bloated. Its major moments are thematically and narratively confused. It needs a HUGE rewrite if it was ever to be told as a Game of Thrones style epic story with that level of public traction. As an example, the thematically key moment in the final book is when the Emperor decides to reject ascension to being the Dark King and stay humanish. The prophecy of the Dark King isnt even mentioned until The End and the Death II the penultimate book, he is talked down from it by a character Ollanius Persson whos introduced as barely a B plot in book 19 and not mentioned again until book 58. Its honestly a little bit of No one has had a better story than Bran the Broken vibes! Now imagine frontloading the Dark King prophecy to Book 1 where Loken encounters Sammus. We are encouraged to first of all think the prophecy is about Sammus a demon antagonist of a few books, then Horus, then were unsure if its Horus or The Emperor. It could have been a really interesting mystery and throughline to the whole series. But if you did edit all of this, fans will be pissed. They hate lore retcons. So its the classic dilemma that these kinds of IPs face when adapting for a general audience You can edit your story to be more generally accessible, but this probably changes some elements in some ways that will upset a part of your fan base.
This is true, but Im not sure Id classify them as a gaming stock in the traditional sense? Because theres such a strong retail presence behind the company.
Yeah. I think the deal has a chance of falling through myself. Its not there yet. I dont currently own any GW but was considering getting in prior to the deal but alas no funds at the moment!

I would be careful with what you wish for. A lot depend on what Amazon want to do with a warhammer story. If GW is starting to change lore, they may loose their core customer base fans who spends on physical product. E,g, seen on other IPs. Amazon would be great if they use the setting as it is.
But its also kind of all irrelevant to my stock position as Im not planning on taking a long term position here.
Who can say on the Amazon deal. Maybe look at insider buys for a clue?

Huh? Centrus energy still has PE of 15. It had quarterly revenue of 189 M and net income of 30 M in June. YOY profit increased by 140. The current GAAP PE is 14.5 the forward GAAP PE is 26.49. At 56 it was 51 PE. That would make its current PE around 89. LEUs revenue stream is extremely blocky and not seasonally predictable. Note that in Q1, it missed revenue and earnings expectations by almost as wide a margin as it beat them in Q2. I invested in it for the fundamentals. This is even before the AI hype. Now I am sitting with profit of 70. Are you sure you are looking at the right company? Yes, I am looking at its cleanedup balance sheet over the last 5 years. Certain segments of LEUs fundamentals have deteriorated over this time. Here is the return on assets, EPS, and PE from 2019 to 2024 YearPEEPSROA 2020184.5653.9 202116.32.8052.4 202241.43.8431.2 202365.04.3926.0 2024 current89.41.488.7 In terms of positioning within the industry, LEU is one of the best picks. Ok Ill be honest I dont understand most of your comment lol. I was looking metrics on Google Finance tab and in Morningstar website. Both give EPS of 5.44 and PE of 15. The revenue has been increasing for past 4 years with profit margin 25. Yes, I know thats what the official 10K and 10Q reports say. Unfortunately, retail investors are rarely privy to accurate accounting data. The buy side never takes 10K and 10Qs at face value they pay their analysts to pull apart and rebuild financial statements so they can discern which companies are good investments. I dont understand how the PE can go from 15 to 90. If that is indeed true then is the company is cooking up data? Im confused lol. Yes and no. The problem is with how GAAP allows companies to categorize revenue, earnings, goodwill, free cash flow, etc. They get considerable optionality in what they include or dont include. This means company balance sheets are incompatible. Even if theyre in the same GICS subindustry, they are using a different set of criteria for what are putatively the same metrics. Additionally, they get penalized when their accountants arent savvy enough to play the game properly. Mind you, for the last two decades the correlation between stock prices and earnings has considerably strengthened. Investors expect earnings to continuously grow and beat analyst expectations. It is in the companies best interests to fudge the headline numbers to make themselves look as good as possible. I dont know if LEU does any tomfoolery as egregious as Soundhound labeling contract termination fees as revenue, but their official reports dont match the database Im using. And I trust the latter far more. Can you give me a link to your data? Or are calculating it yourself based on the earnings reports? If youre willing to shell out several thousand dollars, sure! Thats how much I pay to access this information.

Like some of the newer stuff Ive been buying into is around naval companies and components for drones. The naval stuff is because we are way behind in the US in what we need and we dont build here. The United States effectively gave up on commercial shipbuilding during the Reagan administration in the name of free trade. In the decades that followed, generous state subsidies helped China dominate commercial shipbuilding, and Beijings requirement that the sector be dualuse resulted in an industry that can shift to production and ship repair for the military during a conflict, much as U.S. shipyards did during World War II. The U.S. Office of Naval Intelligence estimates that China now has 232 times the shipbuilding capacity of the United States. China built almost half the worlds new ships in 2022, whereas U.S. shipyards produced just 0.13 percent Rebuilding the arsenal of democracy that anchored the U.S. victory at sea 80 years ago wont happen overnight or cheaplyit is a generational project. The 20year Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Program aimed at upgrading dry docks, facilities, and equipment will end up costing well over the projected 21 billion But the plan is only intended to maximize existing U.S. industrial capacity and wont do much to close the enormous shipbuilding gap with China. That would require a reconstitution program on par with the series of maritime laws passed after World War I, which supported the expansion of an industrial base eventually capable of turning out thousands of carriers, destroyers, submarines, frigates, and cargo ships for the Atlantic and Pacific fleets.

The insurance for the waste is one of the biggest prohibitions to nuclear waste. It essentially needs to be guaranteed forever, this results in the only ones willing to take the risk being states and countries.

It is not 75000 years to store waste. Low and intermediate level waste is stored for 30 years in cooldown pools before being buried is ceramic pucks, and hight level waste is stored for 50 years before being buried. High level waste loses 99.9 of its reactivity in 40 years. The worst high level waste is back to background level within 100010000 years. The Navy has stored all of its waste generated over the last 60 years of nuclear power in a single spent copper mine. 95 of waste is low level. 0.2 is high level, with intermediate making up the difference. 30 percent of all used fuel is reprocessed for reuse in reactors and a small percentage is refined for medical use. As for the cost. Long term storage for is estimated 10 of the total cost of the reactors lifetime expense, and is required by the government to be set aside to cover all costs.

Nuclear waste is an extremely over exagerated problem. The entirety of highly dangerous nuclear waste produced in France from the past 40 years fits into a single cube with sides measuring 15 meters. And Its the most nuclearized country in the world, and the total amount of carbon free energy produced for so little waste is absolutely outstanding.

The fear of another Chernobyl, TMI, etc... forced the industry to be regulated to the point that for most companies it wasnt financially viable. The company I work for used to own Talen energy mentioned in this article the reason it was sold off is because it was just dead weight back then. Perfect example...at the Susquehanna plant mentioned, we had to keep two fleets of excavators on hand in case of a meltdown and pay for upkeep, maintenance, etc... It was literally redundancy for a black swan event, wild. This is the reason that Exelon has basically been the name in the game in nuke generation in the US. My old boss used to head up exelons nuke operations the only way they were able to make it profitable was through acquisition and absolutely ruthless standardization...they acquired a new plant and would implement the playbook...execsemployees who pushed back were gone. Same service intervals, same vendors for IT systems, same schemes, same excavator, same everything across the entire fleet. My company, as many others have long said nuke is the answer...with reasonable regulation. SMR and the involvement of big tech is bringing that conversation to the forefront. Nuke and nuke adjacent industries like utilities are great play at the moment. Same with NG, but thats a whole other discussion.

On top of that, the fact is the more you engage in a risky activity the greater the odds of something bad happening from said activity even if the odds are really really low. i.e. the average driver could correctly boast having a 100 safety record, but obviously youd rightly laugh in their face if they insisted that means theres zero chance that theyll ever get into a car accident. Even if you have a bunch of very safe drivers on the road, the more very safe drivers you have on the road the greater the odds that one of those very safe drivers will get into an accident, it happens every day because theres millions of them on the road. That above paragraph isnt fear mongering about nuclear energy, its statistical odds.

Your fallacy is in attributing the causes of previous nuclear incidents all to operator error. Humans make mistakes, of course, and Chernobyl management was definitely negligent and reckless. However, what made Chernobyl a disaster was shoddy reactor design that wouldve never been possible in the West. I mean, hitting the shutdown reactor button is what caused the Chernobyl reactors to explode! Same goes to Fukushima with its backup generator design and way too tiny tsunami seawalls. Its not just the Wests operational practices that have made nuclear energy so safe here. Its that reactor facilities have been designed with passive safety in mind to prevent operator error from ever causing a disaster, and the next generation nuclear technology takes that to another level. Its like saying cars in the 50s were so dangerous because even minor accidents could kill or cause severe injury, so people just shouldnt drive. Sure, operators need to improve, but the cars themselves could get a whole lot safer, and they have!

when the consequences of just one mistake at a nuclear plant could be catastrophic. replies.text: Its probably a disqualified disposition. With an ESPP as you noted if you sell it without holding it for 2 years the sale is treated as ordinary income. Also it a question for your employer HR not Fidelity especially since its on your paystub. Its reported on your paystub so you can do your taxes correctly. Its not necessarily a problem it just means that your taxes would be higher than if you held on to the shares for 2 years.
Its a tax issue. Learn as much as you can about this plan if you are going to put serious money into it.

On Employee stock purchase plans and corporate stock options There are often blackout dates during which you cannot sell shares and other restrictions that may very from company to company. So you need to review the terms and conditions before you sell. If you sell during corporate blackout period you could be charged with insider trading and could end up in jail.

Curious on opinions about this mindset Participate in ESPP. Money is autosetaside for 3 months then used to buy at the 15 discount. Wait until a 30 day blackout period passes then sell immediately. Unless the stock has weirdly tanked, but lets assume a somewhat steady stock and Im basically cashing in the 15 return. The gains are taxed as regular income, but thats okay because hey, its 15 free money before taxes. Versus holding for 2 years which seems like a much longer exposure to the price moving down even on a somewhat steady stock. While anything could happen during the 30 day blackout, it seems like a lot more of anything could happen during a 2 year hold. Sure, if it works out the taxes are lower, but if it doesnt then Im left holding stock thats worth less than I paid. It seems like simple question of risk tolerance, but are there other drawbacks to the sell quick approach?

It is personal risk tolerance. But its also about how much you know about the industry of your employer and the business itself. I personally like to have skin in the game. If Im working some place its because I believe in the business. I still have shares from an employer that Ive been slowing unwinding more than 5 years after I left the company.

A friend of mine at work and I both used to take advantage of our company ESPP which was the same as that described by OP except for the 2 year hold requirement. We had no hold requirement. This let my friend sell at the end of each period and get a nice bump on his money. I decided to hold on to all my stock purchases and take the risk even after I left the company. It worked out well for both of us, but for a long time the company Microsoft stock price just hovered in the upper 20s. It wasnt until 2013 that it started going up. It was risky, but I had confidence in the company and the industry. I lucked out. It really does come down to whether you have enough confidence in the company to bear the risk.

Thats a great cost basis and I hope you still have some of that MSFT stock. Fwiw the 2 year requirement isnt an employer decision. The tax is based on whether the ESPP is qualified section 423 qualified or nonqualified. If Microsoft had a nonqualified ESPP that just means that you paid the taxes when you purchased the stock at ordinary income levels.
Ah! Thanks! That does clear it up!

replies.text: When was the last time you actually heard of a brokerage going under? Banks fail every now and then ... but brokerage houses?? If your brokerage fails, the economy has FAR, FAR BIGGER problems and diversifying aint gonna be on the list of things you can do about it. TLDR there are more important things in investing to worry about.

This all seems very specific for your country so youd be better off asking investorseconomists within your country. And honestly dude, you can say where you live. If anyone cared about your residency we could just a check your comment history and b trace your IP adress. As for your question it all depends on your local laws. If 90 is protected its irrelevant how much you diversify, 90 is always 90. If its 90 or X amount of money in the account, then diversification matters. Secondly when using a broker theyll adhere to the laws in their country. So Interactive brokers follow the rules and regulations based on where they have their seat, not where you are. Thus youd probably be better off using a local broker if you want your national laws to apply. Last buy not least invested money is seldom if ever protected. Laws tend to safeguard money that is not invested, cash on the account. Money you have invested isnt money, its shares of companies and those shares are owned by you and not Interactive Brokers or anyone else. If that broker goes bankrupt youd still own your shares so that is another factor to consider. TLDR Ask someone in your country, we dont know. Money is often protected, but not stocks...because brokers dont own stocks. They merely handle them for you and thus its irrelevant if they go bankrupt, they legally cant touch your stocks
I do it, no matter how much they tell me that any one of them is too big to fail or that my securities are going to be safe anyways.

My wife had a vanguard account from work, and my work used fidelity. Neither of us still work, but we keep them separate as an added safe guard. A brokerage doesnt have to go under to cause you pain. Their systems could fail, get hacked or whatever. You may not be in risk of losing all your money, but in the event of something goes south, you dont know how long it may take for them the fix your account. Could be days, could be months. Dont want to get stuck depending on one source.

Why not? Ive never purposely done this, but between my wife and I, we have over 20 different accounts. Ive tried rolling overconsolidating a bit in the past, but its such a huge pain, I dont worry about it anymore. Whats one more account to manage? Makes little difference.

Its not a bad idea to have a couple of institutions just because one may be temporarily unable to release funds to you through no fault of your own see the kerfuffle about Fidelity restricting withdrawals due to the proliferation of check fraud lately.
Unless you have some very specific problem e.g. you live in North Korea then this will never be an issue If the largest brokers went down youd care more about bottle caps than green backs

I always do business with a public company that got physical offices in major cities so if I am in London, New Yourk or Hong Kong I can walk in and do business. Being a public company it takes an act of congress to bail out if in default. Before that I know their credit, reputation went to hell already.
Personally I dont see the necessity.
IBKR is a publicly traded company, so you can always follow them and see how their business is doing.

Custody assets are segregated from house assets, meaning that you should only have fellow customer risk. Brokers going bankrupt indeed does happen rarely, and I would not consider interactive brokers someone at risk, but neither was the thinking at the time about MF global. Its only prudent to consider who you are financially in bed with. Even if youre not to take any action on it right now.

Just put your money in a money market or a bond such as ticker BIL. That doesnt need to be insured, you OWN it.
