replies.text: You are taxed on the value of withdrawals. Nothing else. Trade all you like though I dont actually recommend trading too much. Also stay away from weird stuff technically there are some investments that can generate tax even inside an IRA, like MLPs and some of the more esoteric real estate tickers.
Anything that happened inside the account is ignored. Withdrawals after retirement age are treated as income at the dollar value of the withdrawal.

Capital gains are not calculated at all. In a traditional IRA you pay income tax when you withdraw, according to whatever the tax rates are at the time of withdrawal. In a Roth IRA, you pay income taxes now and pay nothing when you withdraw. Thats it.

Its all regular income. Doesnt matter where the funds came from or how the gains were made. Makes me wonder if at some tax brackets whether you do better outside of a retirement account with just a taxable brokerage.

in my traditional IRA or traditional brokeragelink 401K product, I could be generating a lot of capital gains, which if they can not be offset by capital losses, Yes and no. Think of the account as a pool. Yes, losses will take down the total value and gains, interest and dividends will increase the total value. That means losses, while not reportable and having no tax advantage, offset growth of any kind. That isnt tax advantaged. Its just like a tide up and down, up and down. Everything inside a traditional, tax deferred, account is unrealized growth or gain or loss. When you take distributions, they are ordinary taxable income. Whether you are taxed or not depends on how they affect your entire financial picture. Thats why the concept for converting to Roth over time should be ended in the year you turn 62. Years 63 and 64 are the lookback for IRMAA, for Medicare at 65.
When you pull the money out its taxed as ordinary income. Just like if you got paid for working.
After are 59.5, your withdrawals are taxed as regular income not as capital gains and follow regular tax tables depending on income.
I have been trading out of an IRA for many years. At this point I have to take an RMD. But only withdrawals from the IRA are taxed.

Total. Even RMD after 70.5 age is taxed yearly. For example, if your taxable IRA was worth 500,000 at the end of 2023 and you were taking your first RMD at age 73, your RMD would be 18,868 500,000 divided by 26.5. That number is changed each year until all cleared. The additional 18,868 is added to other income so it is not that bad.

The only thing I would add is trading in IRAs can trigger wash sales. That is, if you sell something outside of your retirement account at a loss and rebuy it in your IRA, that will trigger wash sale rules.

Yes, tax can be generated in an IRA, I typically see it when people want to use retirement assets in a self directed IRA and invest in real property syndications in LLCs, debt financed property generates UBIT and UBTI and can carry tax on the IRA due to the debt financing. You can, however, get around this if you have self employment and a self directed 401k, as the 401a rules are different and dont carry tax on the UBIT from debt financed real estate. Down side for some in either case is no self dealing, meaning you cant go purchase a rental home and be the one to manage and do repairs, it needs to be third partys that perform the work on it.
Well not quite, taxes are still generated on dividends, esp foreign dividends. And dividends themselves are reported on a 1099.
No, you would be better off doing Roth.

So I like to think about it like this pretax tool purposes lower taxes today meant to be taken out little by little at retirement age. That is just the characteristics of the tool in general. This is where planning is so important. One persons retirement might be professional grandpa so it just needs to cover bills pretax awesome, take little by little. Another persons might be jetset, tons of popping bottles pretax prolly not good, spending a lot, and all at once, no bueno. Knowing whether you are using the right tool always depends on knowing the job that needs to be done. I dont get mad at clients that just keep it simple in taxable. They could be better optimized, but simplicity can help go wayyyy harder on saving than procrastinating because the taxes arent optimized...
At higher income you are better off with traditional to get that juicy tax break now. At lower income you are better off with Roth.
Yeah, I bought shares in a nat gas supplier in Texas with IRA money. Their distribution yield was over 10! I thought great. I received a 1099 next tax season.
This is only the case if you own foreign stocks and the foreign country taxes the dividendsgains because they dont recognize the IRA or 401k taxdeferred status.
Really? Ive never paid any taxes on dividends in my Simple IRA retirement fund, as far as I know!
Of course that is true. But beyond Roth limits, are there circumstances where a taxable account beats a traditional 401k for taxes?

I think it would be a really limited scenario. Probably a situation where you have a low top tax bracket now so its not worth the deduction and have 0 capital gains in retirement because you have no taxable income and you just take money out of the brokerage. Anything above that 12 marginal rate or so, its tough to argue that the brokerage account will work out better because typically your tax rates are expected to be lower in retirement. But honestly, I havent crunched the numbers, so I cant say its not possible. Of course, not knowing future tax rates will always make everything an educated guess.

The only scenario I can think of is where your tax brackets when withdrawing from your 401k are higher than the combination of the capital gains and initial income tax for the investment principle that would go into the taxable account. Youd have to be withdrawing annually at least 15 more than youre making now, which is usually more typical for someone early in their career, but that person should be contributing to a roth anyway, and likely wouldnt have a lot of spare scratch to throw in a taxableaccountthattheyretreatingasaretirementaccount.

ok, I can think of a scenario You plan to retire very early, so you wouldnt be allowed to withdraw from your retirement accounts without penalty, and your capital gains tax brackets will be low because you wont be collecting social security.

What if you a lifetime floor under your taxable income that put you in a higher tax bracket than the max capital gains tax rate? No low income years to convert a traditional account. Im wondering when the lower taxes on capital gains might make more sense to invest outside of that kind of an account.

In that case you would simply convert traditionalRoth, wait 5 years, and then withdrawal penalty free. Look up the Roth Conversion ladder for more details. In fact, if youre retiring early and plan to have many years of reducedno income, you want as large of a pretax account as you can get. As an example, a married coupile filing jointly could, every year, convert 29,200 current standard deduction and pay 0 taxes on the entire amount. Retire 10 years early and you could easily slip 300k through without paying a dime in taxes.

The goal is to maximize wealth. Every dollar not paid in taxes today allows you to save more meaning your wealth is even more after compounding. Yes you will pay taxes but you have more wealth to begin with.

Im having trouble following, can you clarify? If youre planning to stop earning income and start withdrawing the converted contributions 5 years in the future, wouldnt that mean you would still need to have income at the time of the conversion, and would be taxed for the 30k that youre converting?

I need to work up some detailed spreadsheet models on this. I suspect it depends on timeframe. In the short run say 28 years I suspect the lower capital gains rates may make the retirement fund cost you more in taxes.

The idea would be to rely on your nontaxadvantaged accounts or alternatively you could withdraw your prior Roth contributions for no penalty for your 30kyear income requirements over those 5 years. For an average married couple, if you were selling off assets in your brokerage account you could possibly even realize capital gains taxes at the 0 bracket limited to 94,050year in total income after standard deduction. Its called a roth conversion ladder because, every year, youre converting over money that you expect to use after 5 years, essentially building another step in the ladder to be used as you continue climbing.

That is the general idea. It is called a Roth conversion ladder. Yes it does require 5 years worth of spendable assets outside the trad IRA account. Those could come from Roth contributions andor taxable brokerage account however once setup you can essentially convert and then withdraw as much as you need on a 5 year delay. On year 6 you draw tax free the conversion from year 1, in year 7 the conversion from year 2, etc, etc, etc.

It will not. Remmeber you have to compare apples to apples. It isnt 10k in trad IRA vs 10k in a brokerage account. Yes in that case you should absolutely do the brokerage account. The 10k in an IRA however would give you a tax break and at max rate that is 38 up front. So you could invest 16,120 into an IRA and after the tax break of 6,120 it would cost you 10,000 out of pocket OR 10,000 into a taxable brokerage account. Also keep in mind tax drag on the taxable brokerage account and if you are in the top tax brackets you pay an extra 3.8 on capital gains so the 20 LTCG becomes 23.8. Yes in the taxable brokerage account you will pay less taxes. Absolutely true. You will pay less taxes though simply because you have less wealth to spendwithdraw meaning you end up with less wealth after taxes. The combination of an upfront tax break likely at the highest tax rates of your life plus tax defered growth is massive. The only scenario a taxable brokerage account would come out ahead is if your income is very low now AND will be higher in retirement but no so high that you go beyond the 0 LTCG bracket. Even in that case you might as well go Roth.
Ok, I think I understand, thanks for taking the time to explain

I have a very specific tax situation which means that the upfront tax break isnt really a reduction but more a deferral Its a deferral for everyone but the assumption is that youll pay the tax on the contribution at a lower rate later. I still owe the tax, I just owe it in a future year where my income will still be high. In the meantime the gains are taxed at a higher rate. Thats the nuance I want to model and understand.

Again if your tax rates apples to apples meaning income to income are higher in retirement then now then yes taxable brokerage account would be better than a trad IRA but a Roth IRA would be even better. Tax rates higher now than in retirment trad IRA comes out ahead Tax rates lower now than in retirement Roth IRA comes out ahead Tax rates identical between now retirement Both Trad IRA and Roth IRA come out identical in aftertax wealth so pick one or hedge your bets and split the difference. There are niche scenarios where taxable brokerage account comes out better than a trad IRA but none where it comes out better than BOTH trad IRA and Roth IRA.

Tracking all of that. Ive researched this and cant find much on the third option which is the taxable brokerage in comparison to those two options. In the case of the Roth the tax rate on gains is 0 and the tax rate on the contribution was my rate at the time of the contribution. In the case of traditional, my tax rate on both contributions and gains is regular income tax rates at the time of withdrawal. In the case of the taxable account the tax rate my current regular rate on the contribution and a lower capital gains rate on the gains. Im assuming the tax drag will be minimal if I invest in low distribution ETFs. What Im considering is whether the difference in taxes on gains will be enough to offset the effects of deferring taxes on the contribution. Over a long enough period the deferred accounts definitely win. But over a shorter time period Im not sure.

In the case of the taxable account the tax rate my current regular rate on the contribution and a lower capital gains rate on the gains. This is not the right way to think of it. The amount your taxable amount will grow is dependent on how much you start with, and that is impacted by your tax rate at contribution time. This means that your entire final balance in the taxable account reflects the impact of the taxes you pay upfront. Then you pay capital gains on top of that. You can never outrun the impact of that initial decision to pay some taxes. Every dollar you end up with is going to reflect being taxed as ordinary income at some point of the process. Heres a simpler way to think of it. Roth is always at least as good as taxable assuming you dont withdraw growth early. Its the same starting amount and the same growth, but with definitely no extra taxes instead of maybe no extra taxes at withdrawal. And Roth is easier to compare to Traditional, because it just comes down to which end you expect a better tax rate from at contribution time, or withdrawal time. If your pretax amount is P, your aftertax percentage is A, and your growth factor is G, then comparing the two is Traditional PGA Roth PAG ... and those will only differ for the same money by the difference in A. Taxable is PAG minus some capital gains taxes.

replies.text: FNILX technically isnt the SP 500. It uses an index designed by Fidelity of 500 US large cap companies. Diversification and slightly better returns historically. Most tdf usually use total stock market for U.S. exposure. Large cap and total stock market have pretty similar returns recently I would rather take extra diversification for me personally.

replies.text: Yes you can buy at any time. If you look at a price chart notice that there is zigzag pattern which is the value of the underlying treasuries accruing interest value and a drop whenever distributions occur. But be aware that SGOV can be more sensitive to sudden interest rate changes very rare. But because it has an ultrashort duration of less than 3 months as long as you hold the position for at least a month or two your capital is preserved.

It doesnt matter when you buy. The price will climb as returns accumulate and then drop when the fund pays dividends out. The net value at the instance before and after the dividend payment is the same, except the money is either in the fund price or its in your account. Timing doesnt matter.
It feels nice if you buy right after the distribution, but it makes no mathematical difference.
got it, thanks. Any benefits for SGOV compared to money market funds like VUSXX?
You can buy sgov almost anywhere. vusxx vanguard and maybe ETrade but there arent a lot of places you can buy it without a purchase fee if you can at all.

Generally speaking its about the yield curve. SGOV will have a longer duration than a money market fund. So the yield should in theory be a little higher. SGOV is also exchange traded so you can invest in it at any broker. It really depends on your own needs.
Slightly higher yield. Exempt from state and local taxes
VUSXX is a treasury fund so its also exempt from state taxes.
But not 100

replies.text: Be warned, you say you dont want to be a stock picker, but thats exactly what youre asking how to do. The M1 Finance platform is set up to automatically rebalance and buy fractional shares. You then need to decide for yourself how you want to balance everything. Ill make up some numbers for an example. Suppose you want 20 in finance stocks, 20 in tech stocks, 20 in energy, and so on. Then you look at your stocks from the sp 500 list, and you started with 20 finance stocks, but you cut out 10 for whatever reason. You could then just decide to buy 2 of each remaining or use a stock screener to find 10 replacement stocks. Edit Look at the VOO portfolios composition for an example of how they do it.

I find it hard to believe someone interested in ethical investing could find 450 massive companies that they dont find deplorable. Truly the best advice if to put these beliefs aside and just buy VOO. What you do as an individual makes basically no impact, take care of yourself and maximize your returns.
How many stocks are you planning on having in the fund? How often are you going to rebalance the weighting? It seems like a lot of work to keep on top of with very little benefit in returns.
Just buy the index. Vote your beliefs, invest to generate wealth. Youre signing up for so much pain trying to manage this yourself.

The easiest way to achieve this will likely be through a direct indexing product, many of which will allow you to exclude specific stocks. However, direct indexing products generally carry higher fees and higher minimums and of course excluding many companies will affect returns and potentially introduce tracking error.

Regarding your comment OP, could I suggest something like the VEGN ETF There are ETFsindicesfunds for ESG investing, so people can choose to not invest in smoking, gambling, or other controversial businesses not touching the ethical and philosophical landmines of say, a nonoil fund investing in Wells Fargo who in turn invests in oil. The US Vegan Climate ETF has a market cap of 100M and is heavily concentrated in tech. Feel free to research more that fit your intention.

Index funds are constantly rebalancing to match the SP 500. Youre not going to be able to devote the time to this homemade index to get the returns you could from a real index fund. Plus Im pretty sure youd pay an assload of taxes. Look into sustainablegreen mutual funds and ETFs, if you really cant get over this mental hurdle. But your portfolio will not be as successful as people following the generic guidance of VOO and chill, or similar.

I am not trying to be a stock picker. Proceeds to pick out stocks. If you want to pick stocks, then pick stocks, but dont pretend youre creating an index. Picking individual stocks is the way to get rich in the market, but you gotta pick the right ones. That there is the crux of the biscuit.

An index fund follows an external index a recipe that you license from an index provider. You invest in what it tells you to, in the amounts it tells you to, and in that manner you track your index. If you want to create your own fund, and do your own research, and actively manage your own fund, please do so ... itll be great experience for you ... but it absolutely will NOT be an index fund.
buy individual stocks

replies.text: A million dollars sounds like a lot, but its not enough to retire at 45. Specifically, you wont be able to safely generate 100kyear. You would need to save more money around 2.5 million, to generate 100kyear. The best way to do that is to make more money at your job, not by investing better. You could look into the FIRE communities resources for the math around what it takes.

Lots of things to consider, I think. Making 12 is not guaranteed, for example. 100k will have less spending power after inflation. You will also need to pay taxes on it. SP500 over time is about 7 but that does account for inflation. If you can go five more year investing 4kmonth you should easily more conservatively hit 1.5 million. Its still not enough for me to feel like Id be comfortable retiring on but itd be closer to the 50k after taxes that you plan to be living on for the next 10 years. And retiring at 49 still seems kinda awesome.

You are going to need closer to 2 million if your yearly expenses are 100k TODAY. And with inflation in 10 years you probably need closer to 3 million. Your withdrawal rate should be about 35. So 1 million at 4 is only 40k expenses per year. Frankly at 34 you should not be near burnt out from working. You might need to reevaluate or take some time off and recharge. Another option is to quit your full time job with 1 million. Cut some expenses and work an easy part time job. You would withdraw 40k from your portfolio and your part time job would fund the rest of your expenses

You have the right idea but your numbers dont work. You unlikely not going to make 12 a year over 10 years. You will need a lot more than 1million to generate 100k income per year on a relaiable long term basis.

There are a couple parts of this where to invest and what to invest in. Where should you be investing? You should prioritize tax advantaged accounts, which means your 401k, if available, and IRA. Dont bother with an aftertax account until those are maxed out. Then theres choosing what to invest in. Youll get 2 main schools of thought on this 100 SP500 index fund higher volatility, but probably higher gains 3 fund portfolio lower volatility, but slightly smaller gains You can look at the bogleheads wiki for details about the 3 fund portfolio if thats something youre interested in. Those arent the only approaches, but they will be the right choice for 95 of individual investors.

1 million with 50k expenses and the flexibility to be willing to work an easy part time job if needed. That is very doable. The reason you would work part time is when the market is down big. If the market is down 40 you dont want to be withdrawing 50k from your portfolio when stock prices had tanked. Even if you only make 30k that will help your portfolio immensely.

When you think about your expenses with early retirement, dont forget healthcare. I had to get healthcare through the marketplace for a few months before becoming Medicare eligible. Since my income was too high for a subsidy, I paid about 1100month for a high deductible Silver plan.

replies.text: Also, dont think of debt as only a bad thing. Understand the difference between bad debt vs good debt. Many people have been able to leverage low interest rate debt into great investments, whether property or businesses or other avenues to increase wealth.

You seem like a nice guy. So the best advice for you should be to open up a roth ira. Or a traditional ira, but most likely roth They are tax advantaged accounts. They are so advantageous that your contribution is capped at a certain limit per year Youre only allowed 7k per year right now. In your brokerage, you will be paying taxes on your gains every year. Which limits its growth
Fidelity or Schwab god tier ETF I recommend to start with VOO
M1
SCHD, JEPQ, VOO

You already opened up two brokerage accounts? You are looking for a third? SPLG equivalent to VOO is my recommendation for an ETF. You can also focus on more growth focused ETFs. I prefer QQQM myself. SCHG is a decent growth fund as well. Bonds would be a waste of growth potential. Unless you need the money in the short term.

Theres nothing wrong with using RH for basic investing. It lacks advanced industry tier trading tools, but you shouldnt be trying to day trade stocks anyways. The safest way you can invest in stocks is to go 100 into VT and make regular contributions throughout your lifetime. Its a globally diversified index fund capturing essentially all investable developed and emerging markets. You cannot be more diversified in stocks than this, and although you could add bonds you shouldnt need to do that for at least another 15 years. The two things you should absolutely do right now are 1. Open an IRA if you havent already and start making regular contributions. You can do this on Robin Hood or through any other major brokerage. Doing this now will do more for future you than any other single thing. 2. Read Little Book of Common Sense Investing and The Psychology of Money. These more than anything on Reddit should guide your investing principles between now and retirement. These will teach you how to think about money and investing and make your own decisions. Remember that idiots who dont even know what they dont know will log onto Reddit and act like authorities on every subject imaginable, including stocks and investing For all you know youre talking to a 14 year old kid whose investing knowledge comes from memes. Also keep in mind that Reddit skews heavily young and American, and the U.S. has been enjoying unprecedented economic growth over the last 2 decades. The vast, vast majority of people here are post2008 investors who dont even know what a major, lasting downturn or economic depression feels like. Consequentially, there is a lot of bias towards U.S. stocks and people tend to overlook risks in favor of chasing potential returns. The books I recommended will help you develop a more holistic understanding of money and investing and how to balance riskreward in a sustainable manner over multiple decades.
Not a fan of Bitcoin but do as you will. Go with SPLG or VOO.

I have used Etrade for over a decade with no complaints. Open a Roth IRA and contribute 7k a year if you can. Stay away from options and crypto and play the long game. You will retire very wealthy if you are patient.

Debt can be helpful. The basic accounting equation is Assets Liabilities Equity. Notice how liabilities are a part of equity. plenty of things you may want to do in life may require you have credit history which is easily developed by responsibly managing debt over time. Anyway, as others have said theres nothing wrong with RH for most entry level purposes most peoples purposes in general. Also, you can have taxable and taxadvantaged or exempt accountsinvestments. The mix of those mostly has to do with when youll need what amounts of money. We dont know your life circumstances so its silly to tell you how to allocate your money. Also, at your age, while, theoretically, you can take more risk and recover more easily depending on your life context you may need access to your funds more rapidly than you expect. Your life will change a lot over the next 1215 years. I suggest learning some basic accounting and finance. Both seem scary, neither are anything special. You can take a course at your local CC, find aa free open course online, or just read through resources like investopedia.
I would ditch robinhood and go with Schwab or fidelity. Invest in index funds, voo is good like others mentioned.
Fidelity and dont look back. Robinhood blows.

I would also consider that if you are offering a loan, you now have a different group of regulatory bodies to comply with, and I know nothing about legal ethics in this regard. A last thought The best business advice I ever got was dont charge so little you resent your client. Can you afford both financially and mentally that you may work REALLY hard for some people and they may never repay you? This is rpersonalfinance, not rdogoodforotherhumans, so thats the only real perspective Im offering here. I do admire the help youre trying to offer.
There are credit funds that specialize in this. They also buy out annuities, legal settlements, distressed assets etc. if you Google distressed assets funds or sell my annuity you will get a list

I have a friend that does this, in Illinois I was told it was illegal for the lawyer to forward an advance sum of money while the client is waiting for the case to be finalized, my friend has a substantial amount of money available and he partnered with a couple of lawyers, the lawyers are his personal lawyers or friends of his, usually a person would get injured in a bus crash for example and the lawyer would take the case and the client would be fine for a while but towards the end they start getting antsy for money, the lawyer knows it is a done deal and they will be receiving a settlement so when the client asks for an advance they explain that they legally do that but they know someone that does for a fee, my friend would advance the client 50k and in exchange he gets 75k back, the nice part is that the law firm receives the money from the person or place being sued so my friend gets paid back from the lawyer, lawyer takes his 3rd of the settlement and then the lawyer will pay my friend his 75k and then the rest goes to the client. If you can find a personal injury attorney, preferably someone that you know you can start out small, maybe just advancing 510k depending on the size of the settlement, after you do a few deals you start meeting other lawyers or the lawyer you are getting referrals from will tell other lawyers about you. Just remember as any good business you need to give a commission to your referral, you need to make it worth their while, sometimes its a simple as paying for a vacation or a few dinners, it all depends how much you are making. Good luck and remember to pay your taxes on all your profits

Be very careful. Providing financial assistance based on the merits of a case would violate the Model Rules of Professional Conduct You may advance only expenses of litigation at most. Check your states model rules, but this sort of thing is exactly what the Model Rules are trying to prevent.

I believe this is called litigation finance, which Id personally like to invest in, but I havent found a public vehicle yet. Maybe look into Virage, Burford, and Fortress to see if they can help. Hope this helps

Did you even try to search for this? I used Google and theres numerous hits for providers offering this very thing. Also, be careful referring anyone to anything and the ramifications under your professional responsibility rules.
Counselor, you know the rules on this.
I suggest you talk to Scott Rothstein.

Unlike the personal injury case, divorce cases are really hard to predict the outcome. Many states dont support divorce by fault, right? And the asset sales recoveries will be even dragging. and many would just opt in for monthly alimony. Hence, as an investor, i would be hesitate to invest in a 30 year loan that has many uncertainties in it. Attornies can do contingency on divorce cases, but even that becomes rare. In general, you are looking a long term horizon, high fees, high uncertainties and potential dangerous cases murder, revenge, child custody fight etc. Divorce brings out every ugliness in a human being. North Carolina. I am familiar with how my peers do it. The short version is they have not found a solution.

In North Carolina, where I practice, lawyers are allowed to refer a client to a lender and help facilitate, but the law firm representing the client cannot be the investor themselves or profiteer from the referral. My guess is your friend had a colleague at another law firm willing to invest in the loans, which should be ok, so long as the investor does not work for the firm representing the client. Hearings for postseparation support temporary alimony or interim equitable distribution a portion of the assets are common. However, we often have to schedule hearings about 34 months out because of the courts busy calendar. When the other side doesnt cooperate with financial disclosures it can get rescheduled a couple times as we wait for the evidence andor schedule a motion to compel evidence. Sometimes the other spouse doesnt comply with the order either, which adds months more of delays to enforce the order. In other words, sometimes by time the other spouse actually pays on the temporary order, its almost trial anyway. The idea of finding a financing company to provide the funds instead is to avoid the delays of the court system. If they offer a good deal, it may even make more sense for the client to pay interest on the loan rather than pay my fees for temporary hearings. Often, the parties will not agree on anything and the other sides lawyers are virtually nonresponsive. Nothing gets done until a hearing date.

Whats the alternative youre thinking of? In North Carolina see Odell v. Legal Bucks litigation funding is not considered subject to usury limitations, so long as the repayment is contingent on the outcome of the case. In that case, a 40 flatfee interest payment on a 2year loan was upheld.
Because it violates several of our ethical rules most of the time.

Attorneys cannot be investors in their own case by providing lending services to their clients. We can only refer the client to a company that provides those services. Also, divorce attorneys are not equipped to comply with lending regulations, evaluate default rates, etc. Our role would merely be to refer the client to someone that is in that line of business. That would be the litigation financing companies that invest in these types of loans. However, they are generally focused on larger, longer cases commercial disputes, public interest, personal injury. I think the issue from the investors perspective is and Im just speculating is a matter of scale. If the borrower only needs to borrow 30k for one year, the interest rate may not be enough to justify the expense of evaluating the case, default rates, etc. I presume no actual knowledge there are legal caps to how much interest they can charge that isnt enough to justify the investment in evaluating the case and the risks of the loan. So the investor would have to be a not a lawyer and not me b someone with an interest in highrisk, smallscale loans c someone with enough legal knowledge to evaluate. Thats a tough find. That brings us to this post to see if anyone could think of viable options for where I would find such an investor.

Then the answer is the first of the two. If one suffers then move for temporary orders for allowance to be paid out of the distribution OR future spousal. Or, if you really want to have fun, challenge the separate property, move for all to be frozen, then call them about that joint release which is what you do when both suffer, but yeah you can force that too but its better just to get the allowance and let them be stupid and lose money and pay damages.

So you know he solution, and everything you identified has solutions as well. There is no reason the other side isnt enjoying a free three hots if what you said is true. But instead of forcing it as you can, you pretended there wasnt a solution, now agree that there is one but its still difficult, so Ill team up with a third party, who will profit from the case, and who will add additional damages to my client, and say its a good idea. The reason attorneys can say you need to do X but there are no penalties for not doing so is because folks like you just drop the difficult ways to force and establish that norm. Counselor, no.

The alternative is talking to hard money lenders I know and see if any of them are interested. They mostly do constructions loans secured by real estate at 12, so an unsecured loan is going to be materially more expensive.

replies.text: Contributions differ from company to company, for example, for my company our 401k contributions go into the funds the day before we get paid, a previous company the orders traded the day after. And obviously companies have different payroll schedules, weekly, biweekly, semi monthly, monthly, base salary, commissions, quarterlyannual bonuses etc. And then each fund manager allocates cash differently, getting X in contributions doesnt necessarily mean the fund invests X across its underlying investments immediately. At the very least, you need to net the inflows with redemptions, or hold cash for possible upcoming redemptions from at risk clients less of an issue with passive funds Various companys and industry groups track mutual fund inflows, Morningstar for example Broadridge also tracks flows and total assets using the data they get as proxy service provider. They also sell this data back to asset managers. I dont know how good retirement specific reporting is. Public 5500 filings are available but usually about a year behind. ISS owns Brightscope which collects data from asset managers and record keepers but they charge for that data.
Thanks for your insights, I will be looking online at these companies

To me, its just gibberish until you have a goal in mind regarding your portfolio direction. Are you going for growth, value, dividends, early retirement, saving up for a house, trading, or longterm investing? First, define a goal, and then your weights will make more sense to you. You may even throw out stats or add others based on your goals. A weighted average may not make sense. You are limiting your investing factors. I would put down everything that concerns you regarding investing and prioritize the list without percentages. Then, its a simpler process to compare any investment you might consider. I never invest in any security that I know i cant sell liquidity. Thats way more important to me than a PE ratio, Beta, or dividend growth.

I have a loose set of rules to compare securities. With AI, you might be able to compare company financial records. Its hard to compare companies on stats alone because banks have different financial statements than energy companies. I find bank financial statements very confusing. You have to be a bank to really understand banking statements. If i cant understand a companys financial statements, then I dont invest in that company. My rules are based on experience of exposure to risk. I invest by mitigating my exposure to risk and limiting my exposure to risk. My rules are flexible and have exceptions. For example, I never borrow money from anyone else in life. However, there are exceptions to the rule. I would borrow for a house or car. I also have credit cards that I pay off monthly. So, I do borrow when it is beneficial to me, not the banks. I do my best to never invest on margin. I just paid off my margin account, and it was 2400. I had to borrow when the market took a dump a few months ago, and I was short on cash. Another rule I have is I invest in companies that are solvent. This means they have as much cash or cash equivalents they can easily pay off their debts if they had to today. They also should have an excellent cash flow. Investing is an art and a science. Yes, the details matter. However, if you have no goal in mind other than just making money, then the details dont make much sense. Fear drives markets, not the details or stats. If you can predict or guage the fear, you have better chances of profiting from it. Have you looked at bogleheads.org for how to invest?

I mean it just says u have to make 50k in 5 years and another 75 in 10 more years, and it could be more but his goal is to have 50k atleast Right now were using a Monte Carlo simulation to get risk and also another algorithm to get the sharpe ratio but thats pretty much it
But we gotta invest with strategy cuz were ranked based on strategy not returns so I figured doing this would be decent strategy Would u approach this a different way?

So would u say I use these as a rough outline but also accept if outliers and present? And also calculate things like the chances of a recession happening or an expansion in the market, and like consumer confidence?

You need to turn those numbers into compound annual growth rates, using a tvm calculator. Knowing how much return you need will help you decide what assets to include in your universe and allocate risk. Also what data are you backtesting on and what data will the portfolio be tested against during the competition?

In the first part, yes, use them as a guideline. For the second part, its more like trying to figure out where the overall market is going based on current market and global conditions. For example, during the pandemic, I looked for and invested in an oil company because I figured there would be a surge in oil demand post pandemic whenever that would be. So, when people were selling oil stocks, I was buying as much and as often as I could. That was a pretty risky move because that became my number one position in my portfolio, and unfortunately, it still is my number one portfolio position. Its still an excellent position, and I dont regret it. Ive just had to purchase other positions to balance out the volatility of the portfolio. So, you can try to calculate a direction, but its more than that. Its more about a gut feeling based on experience of living in the world knowing fear and then monopolizing on that. Figure out what people really fear, than just market expansion or contraction. Math cant quantify emotions, and thats what drives markets. Fear of missing out drives markets up, and fear of losing value drives markets down. Consumer confidence is only one indicator and indicates what people feared, not what they will fear in the future. I equate market indicators to Doordash hotspots. If you ever did Doordash as a driver, you would understand. They indicate what happened in the past, which may or may not be relevant for now or in the future. There will always be a recession and then upswings. When they happen, be prepared. You can profit from either one. I always have cash or cash equivalents laying around earning money just in case a recession occurs and buy more of what I already own. When an upswing occurs, I tend to hold more than I sell. Im getting closer to my goals, so Im thinking of dipping my toes in swing trading.

I actually think that its the opposite. Edward Jones isnt structured as a corporation with corporate officers. Its a limited partnership. The largest partner is Jones Financial. This type of outsourcing could seriously backfire in the long term if the younger and more successful investment advisers who are not yet partners start to leave Eddiejones. l I do think that many investment advisers do care about their clients and building their book of business. And if an investment adviser isnt able to service their clients they are not incentivized to stay. When investment advisers leave often a big chunk of their book goes with them. So firms like eddiejones, etc. etc. live and die by retaining their investment advisers. And there is a lot of competition among these firms and the large wire houses to recruit successful investment advisers. And RIA platforms and TAMP services like those from Fidelity, Schwab, Pershing, SEI, etc. cater and compete for advisers who want to go independent. Its no secret in the industry that LPL have been poaching successful eddiejones investment advisers. So at eddiejones you end up with investment advisers who either are trying to become a partner or really good ones leave to become their own RIA or they join another firm with their clients. In the long run if the reason for this type of outsourcing by eddiejones is for labor arbitrage, it is likely to fail in spectacular fashion.

Were talking 3,000 8,000 per invoice, so a single mistake can literally cost the company thousands. I estimated recently and it looks like were losing roughly 34 million a year off the mistakes made by this cheaper team. replies.text: No, in general youre going to wait too long and miss out on more gains than you avoid losses. This is why lump sum investing outperforms DCA, on average. Market tends to go up.
removed
During a bull run the market can be up week after week, sometimes for months at a time. If the market is up 15 while youve been on the sidelines waiting for a single digit drop how are you winning.

This isnt dca. But yeah sure this is a thing you could do. Its unlikely to perform well. But you can do it until you decide youve lost enough money and then go back to actual dca. This would ironically work much better on something like bitcoin with huge volatility spikes in both directions but maintains flat pricing over long periods.

Youre much more likely to miss out on gains by sitting on the sideline most of the time. Downturns are inevitable but if timing the market like this usually doesnt work because you have no idea when they will occur.
Ah the weekly, I know I shouldnt time the market but what do you think about my timing the market strategy? post
This would not be beneficial at all.
This is called market timing. Dont do it.

This is the antithesis of DCA. Youre defeating DCA because you are still essentially trying to time the market. You will miss out on gains a lot of the time. Losing out those gains will negate the benefits of moving in on lows. And chances are, you wont be hitting the lows anyway but the middle. So you will likely incur some of the lows while missing out on gains.

Youre ignoring how much upward movement youd miss out on with the money being stockpiled, and assuming this would result in buying at the bottom of a dip. What it would really mean is that youd only ever buy near the peak of each high. Say you been saving up for 4 months because there havent been the right conditions to buy according to your system. Youve missed out on all that up time and its either flat or down from that recent ATH. That doesnt mean its down from where you could have invested when the money was first available, and you dont know what the next period will be. If its up or flat that means the dip was insignificant, making your system pointless since you just bought in the middle of an up streak which is what youre trying to avoid. If its further down, you keep buying with whatever new money you dedicate to investing, but you just invested 4 months worth of contributions, so the next one is going to be insignificant compared to what you just invested at the higher price.
The data is available to backtest this its not hard with excel and a couple hours. Youll see that it simply doesnt work... but you should see that for yourself, rather than taking all our word for it

Thats where my thinking disagrees. In my mind, you wont miss out on most gains as you would have been fully invested at the time of the market bottoming, guaranteed. Even in a bull market there are pullbacks. So if you invest through all of them, the fact that it goes up in general should be maximized. And then on top of it, you do end up semi lump sum investing.

I really wish I had the capability to test this against traditional investing historically. I would be really interested to see the actual numbers on this. I feel like it might have advantages that may at times be more beneficial.

I think this is the best answer here. If you always wanted to invest when trending down, youd have to set a threshold for what indicates trending down. Lets say you set that threshold at 0.6. If the market is dipping for a day 0.5, then raising 2.0 over a prolonged period, youd never buy at the dip and youd miss out on all sorts of gains.

Theres no way to guarantee you buy at the bottom. You may think Ill buy if it dips 10, but then it drops another 20. Or you may think youll buy when it dips 10, and before you know it youve missed out on 60 gains. Its better just to stay invested and to contribute regularly if you can.
This is where are wrong, and the data proves it,

Your thinking is so backwards. Just buy in on red days and hold on green days. Theres at least one red day per week. Its the perfect day to buy cause its cheaper than yesterday. If it stays green a Couple days thats great.
If you dont have the capability to test, then you shouldnt try to make up market timing strategies!
Someone already did it, and DCA wins, as always,

If you had the capability to test, you would be able to time markets... you dont truly understand the concepts being discussed. The best you can do is TRULY carve out your budget, set it to weekly and dont think about it. Time and volatility will make you look like a genius.

I am not talking about pulling out of the market. Just changing the schedule of when the investments go in. Over the course of the year, it still puts the same amount of base money in. And it does guarantee buying near the bottom as you continue to buy all the way down. So the first down turn you do invest all that was held back. But if it continues to fall, that is when you are DCAing the 100 each time after, lowering the cost basis of that batch of shares until the market rebounds to the hold back state.
I dont agree with your attitude here. I cant think about things because I cant test them? Maybe someone should tell physics its done.

What are you talking about? There is software that will historically test a strategy against what the market has done in the past. That isnt timing the market, it is using historical data to fine tune a strategy. People do this all the time. I just dont have access to the software.

The crux of the strategy, to tag onto udogslothbeaver s example, is that by holding your money waiting for the 10 dip the price will have already gone up 12 by time that happens, so, you waited to lose out on 2 of the gains.
Youre allowed to talk about the idea just as much as people here are allowed to respond, if you dont have any hard data backing up your strategy we arent interested in listening
So Grab data from the internet and test in a spreadsheet lol.

LOL. Most of the science of physics can be experimentally tested. But there are realms of theoretical physics that we cant directly test yet but that can still produce models that reasonably match real world observations. Similarly in finance, its exceedingly difficult to know as true fact, that any market timing strategy will work reliably and consistently into the future. But we can use historical data to evaluate if a strategy would have worked in the past and we can evaluate whether there are theoretical risk or behavioral reasons for it to continue to work in the future. You havent attempted to do this and admit that you arent capable of doing it. So Im not saying people with expertise and knowledge shouldnt try to theorize and evaluate their theories as best they can. Im saying that you shouldnt.
You have a spreadsheeting application. You have yahoo finance for data. You can test it.
Whatever approach you decide, test it. If your monthly budget is X, split into regular weekly in one. Your decided approach on the other. You will find Buffet is correct mostly.
Not just the 10 vs 12 you also miss out on the compounding gains

replies.text: It sounds like you have a fortunate family from a financial standpoint that have all made good long lasting financial relationships and have had success with working with financial advisors to manage their money while they have spent time in the business or work earning enough to have extra to invest. That is a powerful combination they have accomplished. It appears your parents and grandparents have consolidated on a set of accomplished advisors. I would move your money to that set of advisors so it will be together with their future gifts. Frankly as much as you like your financial advisor and how helpful he has been to you, you are not a drop in the bucket in his gross income, so he is losing little financially by you moving away. I suspect you are a likeable guy and he is doing it as much as a friend as anything so will be sad to see you go, but will wish you Godspeed and success as you leave. I spent most of my career in a major broker dealer working in a regional capacity and helping our top teams manage their UHNW clients and their families. It is a fortunate thing to be exposed to the level of help you will get from a large accomplished team of HNW advisors. Enjoy the relationship as it builds.

For 3, if youre willing to put some time in, i would suggest finding an hourly financial advisor when you need consultation then using a financial planning tool like Projection Lab to manage your own financial plan. Thats what my fiance and I do. Projection lab is good for modeling different scenarios and it provides nice graphs using your assetsdebtsincomelife events etc. theres a free sandbox mode if you just want to play around w it

In all honesty all are trying to share your wealth. Some have more people skills than others. I often play one CFP against a llc to keep both on their toes. In your case I believe you should have an small account under family plan. From there you do what you feel like that fits your model. Earlier I dealt direct with each company reinvestment department because of high brokerage fees. Later I consolidated into different accounts in a same brokerage that I can walk in drop off signed documents, deposit and talk to them about tax saving plans. Over the years I had many advisors, stock trader Ivy league graduate and had lunch with branch managers and they asked me if I want to apply for ipo stocks and programs not available to many. Most only do as requested with minimal interaction. The one you had for so many years probably never earned much from you but he is a good source for go to questions. I really do not encourage you putting all your savings with same guy family member works with. Best is avoid giving out too much personal question.

I would avoid using ANY family friend as a financial advisor. Dont mix business with personal relationships. Because when you want to end the relationship, its awkward as you are finding out. I also dont see any benefit to using multiple advisors. If you use an advisor, they need to know the whole picture to make recommendations, not just the part invested with them. To break up, you make it short and sweet Weve decided were going to manage our investments ourselves going forward. We appreciate your help and guidance that got us this far and were ready to take over from here. Then you move the investments to your own account wherever you set it up, such as Fideltity, Schwab, etc. by telling the NEW custodian to move the assets from the old one. When your old advisor sees another company requesting the transfer, they will have already heard from you whats happening. Personally I dont believe there is any magic involved in investing. I personallly follow the Bogleheads philosophy so I dont use an advisor, and that system has done great for me. Easy too.

The value of an advisor is to motivate you to do more and organize and automate you. Your long time sounds like he was just getting started, and he is not pushing you hence not worth it. You should put the names of the firms and what the management fees are, and list the biggest mutual funds just the symbol so you can learn how to look up internals. And there is no etiquette for brokerage, if someone is not providing value, you pull the account to someone who will. Most advisors are mediocre just like most employees in any profession. This is a money game, the is the score, biggest number at the end wins...

When I first started working, I always thought I need a FA for investments and I had even asked my colleagues. I was so naive that I kept all my money in savings account paying almost nothing. I moved from another country so I didnt have any clue on IRA and my employer didnt offer 401k. I researched on my own and eventually opened IRA but still was naive enough to not contribute every year. Eventually, I became more intelligent. Just before Covid hit, I was looking at investing 100k that I had been saving. I thought its a big amount, I need a FA to help me invest properly. I met few but wasnt sold on any. So, I decided to do it on my own and I am glad the portfolio has been doing good. Over the last 4 years it has been at least matching SP. We now have a brokerage account, HSA, 2 Roth IRAs and 2 401ks. All retirement accounts have 3 funds FSELX, FXAIX, and VTI in 106030 allocation. I have also learned to feel, one needs a FA after 5m assets or if getting a 1m inheritance. Not only is that a life changing amount but one also needs to do proper tax planning. In your case, I think it is safe to assume, between your parents, your wifes parents and your grandparents, you two are likely to get significant inheritance combined mid 6 figures or may be even more. Hence, having a relationship with a FA would be beneficial. Id speak with both your grandparents and inlaws FA. Understand their plan, their investment philosophy, fees etc, do some research of my own and then pick one.

And studies have relatively consistently proven, that bankers dont really beat amateurs of average intelligence, if I am not wrong. AI will at some point probably understand socioeconomic dynamics underlying wealth movement better than humans. And if that happens, it should usher in a new era of prosperity.

I think one of the most overlooked aspects of AI is being able to infer market moving inflection points before most people can in real time. You can take positions faster on news that isnt relevant at the time, but is one outcome away from materializing. I believe this is the true value of Ai in regards to investing, not fucking triangles.

TA works, but it does not work if everyone has the same model. Your TA needs to be different than what everyone else is using. Because of this AI trading model will not work if you are trading like everyone else. AI will allow you to build your own trading model.
Actually its scientifically proven in the literature that it is pseudoscience and it doesnt work. Fact.

To use QQQ right now as an example the 550 12026 calls with 15 to break even were the type of options I started off with. After building up more money I got a bit more risk averse and now buy ATM with like 12 to break even.

I went into a bit of detail on some of these in my reply to jwp_93 but to summarize I buy around 5 above the ATM price. Option pricing is the main reason I went for XLP. Like, a QQQ leap is the price of 11 shares but an XLP leap is only the cost of 7 shares which could theoretically make up for XLPs lackluster performance. If you meant on a time basis like stocks just went down 30 so volatility is high and options are more expensive I dont take that into account because I dont try to time the market. Never really thought about the greeks, just saw in backtesting that slightly OTM leaps performed better I wont be switching to TQQQ. I wish I could say it was for mathoptimization reasons but I have the if it aint broke dont fix it attitude at this point. I spent a long time forming this strategy 6 years ago and the thought of digging out my old backtesting scripts and updating them with the last few years of data and testing a new leveraged stock strategy against my options strategy to see if maybe its a little better doesnt sound appealing.
Slightly OTM, like 5 above the current ATM price
You could buy leveraged ETF shares or get calls on a highly correlated etf that has a lower share price. Needing 6k to buy even a single ATM leap is a bit crazy for QQQ.

I buy slightly OTM like 5 above ATM price and I got over my fear about buying at ATH by looking at some back testing. As it turns out all time highs are often followed by more all time highs. Obviously the crashes are very attention grabbing so we remember them but on a long term basis the returns have historically outweighed the risks.

Wolfram alpha is great for many situations... For many nottoo crazy equations, it can replace Matlab or Maple, while being more accessible because its less strict on the syntax. Not to mention the free version, which I suppose can be a life saver if you dont get a Matlab license from your school. I have to say, though, that when I discovered Chegg while doing my first semester in engineering physics, I got a monthly subscription and kept it for the whole 4 years. YMMV, though. We were a small program, and most professors didnt use textbooks and created their own material. On every single homework, I didnt even know how to approach 50 of the problems. No textbook in the library had worked examples of similar problems. Chegg often had one worked example of a problem that was at least remotely similar to what I had on my homework assignment. Many professors offered very little office hours, and often at times when I couldnt possibly go... So if it wasnt for Chegg, I was 100 on my own. On the other hand, I had friends in mechanical engineering, and typically the lecturer followed some textbook that contained tons of examples. Basically, they used the nonworkedout problems in the book as homework assignments. In that case, I can see how Chegg is either not worth it, or used by lazy people to have someone else do their homework. As I said, YMMV.

Yeah, I agree, Ive built some models for our sales team thats really great fitting to the past data, but generally is mediocre at predicting future sales results. However, creating dynamically weighted ensemble models while making future forecasts more conservative tends to help with longer term accuracy for us. Our precision tends to be low on a weeklymonthly basis, higher on quarterly, but weve achieved 90 accuracy on year long projections. There is a massive difference though between forecasting something like sales versus the stock market returns, because forecasts can have an impact on the return itself selffulfilling prophecy. Its much better in my opinion to create more narrow projections and model outcomes based on other indicators. For instance, what return can we expect from QQQ if Google and Apple both miss earnings.
